div.p: 1— VII. Thursday—

Finished the version of the 45th. Psalm, and began the 46th.— Ten Psalms in the Month— Some of them seem to me well done; and particularly the 45th—but I suppose there is in reality one vein of general mediocrity running through them all— I had morning visits from General Root and General Pitcher; members of the new house of Representatives from New-York—both of whom have been conspicuous party men in the State, and both heretofore members of the House of Representatives— Mr Nathan Appleton, elected a member of the House from Boston, called also with Edward Everett— Mr Michael Hogan at a very early part of Mr. Monroe’s Administration was appointed Consul of the United States at the Havana—and afterwards in 1822 to Valparaiso in Chili— He first came to this Country from Ireland, with a family, and with a fortune of sixty thousand Pounds Sterling— He lost the fortune; and has been pursued by a series of calamities in South America. He has been recalled by the present Administration; and is here to pass the Winter— His Son is one of the Representatives from the State of New-York— I received a Letter from J. H. Eastburn,—returning Mr. Martin’s Letter, and stating his proposal— Mr. Appleton sent me also a packet, from Miss Eliza S. Quincy, containing two Landscape drawings by her, very beautiful done—one of the foot of Penn’s Hill, with the two houses in which my father and myself were born, and the other the dwelling house where my father last resided, and which is now mine.— There is a Letter with them, and I had received another two or three days since— She has sent them in answer to my Letter to her from New-York; with the Stanza’s on the foot of Penn’s Hill— The two Landscapes, if engraved would form very neat embellishments to a biographical Memoir of my Father.
2. V. Friday.

Visits from Mr and Mrs Hogan, and afterwards from Mr Henry J. Tudor, and from his Sister Mrs E. S. Gardiner, of Hallowell, Maine now here upon a visit to their mother.— Mrs Tudor has been extremely ill, and has not yet wholly recovered— Mrs Stewart is absent, at Philadelphia— Mrs. Gardiner asked me to return the papers of her brother William Tudor, which I have had several months under an engagement that I would write a Memoir of his Life for the North American Review— It was a long time after I had made this promise, before these manuscripts were sent to me; and shortly afterwards Mrs Stewart advised that the publication of the Memoir should be suspended, and finally Mrs Tudor explicitly enough hinted that they preferred it should not be published at-all— The points upon which they were specially sensitive were, an unwillingness that any notice of the fact that Mr Tudor had ever been engaged in commerce—which was his profession during a great part of his life—an aversion to the statement that he had been an informal political agent in Peru, and still more that he had been Consul of the United States at Lima, and not Consul General in Peru— There was even an indisposition to have it appear that Mr Tudor was at the time of his decease, but a Chargé d’Affaires of the United States at Rio de Janeiro— The family would have had him an Ambassador, and would evidently
have been displeased to have it told what he was, though with the most liberal and emphatic commendation of what he did— I had brought the manuscripts to Washington purposely to return them, and was glad that Mrs Gardiner asked for them. I sent them all in this Evening though Mrs Gardiner had written me a Letter to apologize for asking me to return them— I received Letters from George Sullivan, Professor Keating, Dr Charles Everett and R. Rush— Sullivan wishes to obtain a degree at the Columbian College, for his Son George, who was matriculated there; but afterwards went to West-Point where he was graduated in 1829. I walked round the Capitol Hill, before dinner, and returned Mr Appleton’s visit at Gadsby’s, but he was just sitting down to dinner— I met in the avenue Lewis Williams and afterwards Andrew Stevenson with Edward Wyer
3. V:15. Saturday.

Finished the version of the 46th. and began that of the 47th. Psalm— Received visits from Coll. Thayer; superintendant of the Military Academy at West-Point, and from sundry members of Congress— General Dearborn who has been detained on his way from home, by a severe attack of the Influenza, a complaint now almost universal and with which in addition to my other complaints I am suffering not lightly— Phineas L. Tracy, and six other members from New-York, I suppose all Antimasonics were here. I walked to the house of Dr Chapin, President of the Columbian College, and communicated to him the Letter which I had received yesterday from George Sullivan, requesting a degree for his Son George— He told me that it should be granted and that he would write to me, and inform me what would be necessary to be done to obtain it. I had a suspicion that Dr Chapin was a relative of mind, and asked him where he was born— He said at Milford, formerly a part of Mendon in Massachusetts. I told him I thought we were related, and he said there was such a tradition in his family— That his great-grandmother’s name was Adams, and that she came from Braintree— She was the daughter of my Great-grandfather Joseph Adams by his first wife—Mary Chapin and married a person of that name at Mendon.— He said that he had an uncle by the name of Adams Chapin, now nearly ninety years of age, and in good health, with the exception of occasional fits of insanity to which he was subject, and in one of which he now was— Dr Chapin said the Commencement would be on the 21st. of this month, and that they had a Class of ten to graduate. I called twice at Mrs Tudor’s—but the first time they were at dinner and the second Mr Tudor and Mrs Gardiner were gone out— Mr Thomas Newton called upon me this Evening the Old member from Virginia—Norfolk— In the last Congress his Election was contested, and the house most unrighteously decided in favour of his competitor. The people to his great delight have now sent him back.
4. V:30. Sunday.

It being the communion day at the second Presbyterian Church I attended public worship at St. John’s where prayers were read for the second Sunday in Advent, and a Sermon was preached by Mrof Georgetown, from Romans 5.10—“For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God, by the death of his Son much more, being reconciled, we shall be saved by his life”— The preacher was a young man, and his mode of preaching did not accord with the usual practice of the Episcopal Church— He had apparently no notes, and his discourse was apparently extemporaneous— Yet his language was very good, and his delivery very impressive. His doctrine was calvinism in its quintessence— He said the text divided all mankind into two Classes, the friends and the Enemies of God, and it was clear that whoever was not the friend was the enemy of God, or rather of his moral Government. In enquiring who were the enemies of God, it included almost all mankind, and particularly all those who possessed the highest moral virtues, such as charity and benevolence—but practiced them not for the glory of God— The President and his family were at the Church— After the service I called at Mrs Tudor’s, and saw her and her daughter Mrs Gardiner— Mr William Lee was there— Mrs Tudor has been exceedingly ill, and looks very much reduced—Mrs Gardiner proposes to leave this City on Tuesday; to return home— I received visits from Commodore Patterson, from Mr Silsbee, Mr White of Florida, and Mr Swann the District Attorney of this place— Mr Swann seems to be in some perplexity to determine what his opinions shall be, but says he has not changed them these forty years— I told him I had modified many of mine, as admonished by Time and experience.— I intended to have gone to Church this afternoon; but there came up and apparent Snow-Storm; and seemed as if it would obstruct the way. I remained at home and betook myself to writing— Received a Letter from T. L. M’Kenney with a proof sheet of the History of the Indians. Finished the version of the 47th. Psalm—
5. V:45. Monday.— Fahrenheit 13— Sun rose 7:17.

The first Session of the Twenty-second Congress of the United States commenced— Half an hour before Noon I attended in the Hall of the House of Representatives and took the Seat n. 203. At Noon the Members were called to order, by Matthew St. Clair Clarke, the Clerk of the House in the last Congress— The members were called alphabetically by States, and two hundred answered to their names—one or two more afterwards came in— The Clerk sent round the ballot-boxes to collect the votes for Speaker, and when the boxes were returned to his Table, asked Messr. Bates of Maine, Crawford of Pennsylvania and M’Coy of Virginia to act as Tellers— There were only 195 votes returned, of which 98 were necessary to a choice— Andrew Stevenson of Virginia had 98 votes, and was declared to be chosen.— Elutheros Cooke a member from Ohio, brought up his vote to the Table after the other votes had been given in.—The Tellers refused to receive it— His vote was for Joel B. Sutherland of Philadelphia, the principal competitor of Mr Stevenson; who had 54 votes— If Cooke’s vote had been received Stevenson would not have been chosen at that ballot, and probably not at-all— There were votes for John W. Taylor 18. Wickliffe 15; and
some others would have rallied after two or three ballots upon Sutherland; the two Candidates are both men of principle according to their interest, and there is not the worth of a wisp of Straw between their value— Phineas L. Tracy told me that he, and his Anti-Masonic friends had agreed to vote for John W. Taylor and I voted for him— I was pleased that there was not a second ballot; for I was unwilling to be brought to the test whether I would under any circumstances vote either for Stevenson or Sutherland.— He seemed disposed to contest the election, and said he had known yesterday that Stevenson would have 98 votes, and that he could not get one more— The Speaker was conducted to the Chair by Mr Newton the veteran of the house, who administered to him the Oath to support the Constitution of the United States— He administered the same Oath to all the members—calling them up by States—those of the largest States in two or three divisions. Mr Jesse Speight a member from North-Carolina, then moved the appointment of Matthew St. Clair Clarke as Clerk to the House by Resolution which he took from the Journal of the House at the first Session of the last Congress—in this form Mr Speaker, I move the following Resolution— Then without reading it he took it to the Clerk’s table where it was read, and upon the question being put it passed without opposition. The Speaker had made his acknowledgments to the House from the Chair in a short Speech, prepared for the occasion, but not well adapted to the circumstances of his election. Resolutions of notice to the Senate, and for a joint Committee to notify the President were adopted— Resolutions also passed for furnishing the members with newspapers equivalent to three daily; and for the appointment of two chaplains to interchange weekly; and the house adjourned before two O’Clock— There were two districts of Massachusetts unrepresented; seven trials on each of them to hold the election having failed to obtain for any one person a majority of all the votes returned— I suggested to Mr Everett the propriety of a Letter from the delegation to Governor Lincoln, requesting him to recommend to the Legislature a revision of the Law, to secure a full representation to the State at the opening of every Congress— Everett said if I would draw up such a Letter he would sign it. Dutee J. Pearce spent part of the Evening with me.— In the Boston Press of the 2d. instt. there is an Address to the Public, signed by John Bailey, denying the Statement in the National Journal, in the attack upon him and me, some days since.
6. IV. Tuesday.

Russell Freeman was here this Morning, just before the time of the meeting of the house, in great distress about an attack upon him, in the same Boston Newspaper, which has opened upon Mr Bailey and me— He is a member of the Clay Convention which is to meet at Baltimore next Monday; but is not true blue Clay-man enough; can be moreover of little use to that party, because he is deaf as a post; and will hang like a Mill-stone, upon the neck of any party, because he is poor and wants any Office that he can get— Mr Monroe made him Collector of New-Bedford a place from which Jackson turned him out— He told me that in the Event of our party’s regaining the ascendancy, he relied upon me to get indemnified for the place he had lost— But he did not
know what to make of this attack upon him in the Boston Courier; and had thought of going home, without attending the Baltimore Convention— But Mr Everett had advised him to go— I saw he was at Sea, without Chart or Compass, and that it was not for me to give him his reckoning— I told him I was about going to the House and asked him to call again— I attended the House— The Message from the President was delivered and read— Committed to the Committee of the whole House, and 10,000 copies ordered to be printed— Adjourned about 2. O’Clock— I had written a Letter for the Delegation, requesting Governor Lincoln to recommend a revision of the Law of Massachusetts regulating the Election of members of the House of Representatives of the United States— On shewing my Letter to the members of the delegation, I found no objection from any of them to sign it; excepting from John Davis the member from Worcester, who preferred taking time to consider—I know not why.— I bespoke my Newspapers— I wrote another private and confidential Letter to the Governor enclosing to him the President’s Message— Mrs Adams was ill; confined to her bed the whole day— I received a Letter from my Son Charles— And finished the version of the 48th. Psalm—
7. IV:30. Wednesday— Fahrenheit 16-20

Began the version of the 49th. Psalm. Attended at the House of Representatives— John Oswald Dunn was at the second ballot Sergeant at arms— He is a very young man, Son of the person who formerly held the Office— There were several Candidates, and among them was Coll. David Brearley for whom I voted at the first ballot— Overton Carr was chosen Door-keeper at the first ballot He has been sometime the Assistant, and Benjamin Burch the Door-keeper— But he has been for several years and yet is an invalid, confined to his house— Carr’s election, made a vacancy in the assistant’s Office, and there were twelve Candidates successively nominated by different members; and after three ballot’s without effecting a choice, a motion was made, and succeeded to adjourn. Mr John Reed, with whom I had yesterday left my Letter to Governor Lincoln, to obtain the signatures of the members of the delegation who had not signed the paper, returned it to me, signed by all the other members, excepting Davis; who finally declined signing it— He said he was not unfriendly to the object of it but had some doubts whether the remedy would not be worse than the disease. I wrote also a private Letter to Governor Lincoln to accompany that of the delegation— The weather continually very cold—the thermometer all day was between 16 and 20.
8. IV:15 Thursday—

I write till the pen drops from my hand with drowsiness and fatigue, and I have a racking cough which appears to be incurable— It destroys, all my vigour, and bows me to the Earth where to all appearance it will before long deposit me— Mr Cazenove Palfray, the Unitarian minister, came to solicit my vote for the Office of Assistant door-keeper to the House of Representatives— I told him he should in behalf of Moses Poor, have it
but I knew there were two disqualifications, which would defeat any application of Mr Poor for Office—one that he is a yankee, and the other that he is a Unitarian. Dr Condict, Mr Silas Condit, Mr Randolph, and Mr Southard, members of the House from New-Jersey paid me a morning visit— Silas Condit is a son of Dr. John Condit, with whom I sat in the Senate of the United States 28 years since; and he brought me his father’s compliments— Mr Southard is a brother of the Secretary of the Navy that was— These visitors detained me so that when I reached the house the Speaker was in the Chair—The Journal of yesterday had been read, and, he was administering the Oath to two members who came in this morning.— The balloting for assistant door-keeper then commenced—all the candidates but three or four were withdrawn successively—Moses Poor had the highest number till the last ballot—but John W. Hunter of Georgia was chosen at last— Quite an old, and very frequent acquaintance of mine as a candidate for Office— A Resolution for the appointment of standing Committees and one or two others were adopted, and the House adjourned over till Monday— I went over into the Library and examined several Volumes of the British Statutes at Large— I was desirous of ascertaining the state of British legislation upon Free-Masonry and the Administration of unlawful Oaths— I found a Statute of 37. George 3d. ch. 123. (19 July 1797) making the Administration of unlawful Oaths felony punishable by Transportation for seven years—Vol 19. p. 424— And a Statute of 39. George 3. ch. 79. for the Suppression of seditious Societies 12. July 1799. Vol. 20 p. 70—The Sections 5 6 and 7 relate to the Lodges of Free Masons, and allowing them to be held as according to custom heretofore, places them under a strict supervision and custody— Mr Clay and Mr James Barbour called to pay visits; but I had not come home and saw neither of them. Coll. Drayton of South Carolina was here after I returned and I saw him.
9. V:45. Friday.

Finished the version of the 49th. Psalm, and began that of the 50th—both admirable compositions—beautiful Poems—Sublime Lyrics, and in my translations mortifying failures— I cannot write in sickness as in health— In versifying an Ode like the 49th. or the 50th. Psalm, one should be inspired like those who wrote them— I received Morning visits from several members of Congress, and as there was Snow on the ground, and my Cough is growing daily worse and worse I rode out to return visits—Called at the lodgings of Mr Johnston of Louisiana, Mr Clay and General Pitcher, neither of whom was at home— I found General Chambers the Senator from Maryland at his lodgings—and Mr William Biddle Shepard, a member of the House from North-Carolina— Mr White of Florida was also there— At Gadsbys I found Mr, Mrs and Miss Silsbee. Mr Krehmer came in while I was there— I had sent to him with a request that he would forward it a Letter from Mr Middleton, to Count Cancrin the Russian Minister of the Interior— It contains the enquiries respecting the employment of Platina by the Russian Government for coin, which Mr Middleton had at my solicitation promised to make.— Mr Krehmer told me he had received, and would forward it by the first Packet for Liverpool— Mr Silsbee last Spring made some enquiries of me, concerning the character and family of Mr Krehmer, intimating that he was paying his addresses to Miss Silsbee— Since then it has been reported that a schism had taken place.
There was a movement of perceptible reserve this day on the part of Miss Silsbee when Krehmer came in— But none on the part of the father and mother— So I concluded it was the redintegratio amoris that was coming on— I wrote this day to Miss Eliza S. Quincy to thank her for her two Landscape drawings of my fathers birthplace and mine, and of his last Residence and now mine at Quincy.
10. V:15. Saturday.

My cough is becoming so inveterate and racks me so much that I was obliged this day to confine myself to the house— Mr and Mrs Frye were here; several Members of Congress, and the Commandeur Torlade d’Azambuja, the Charge d’Affaires of the King of Portugal Don Miguel— He appears to me a very estimable man, though placed in a very unnatural position— There is no Country in Europe whose revolutions during the last forty years have been so singular as those of Portugal.— One of the most remarkable circumstances attending them is the removal of the Royal Family of Portugal to Brazil, and all the consequences of that event—The separation of Brazil from Portugal—The Establishment of an Imperial Monarchy there—The return of the old king to Portugal, and all the changes that have followed since his decease—The abdication of the Emperor of Brazil, and his return to Europe, an exile now in France, and his younger brother king of Portugal form altogether a series of changes more extraordinary than those in any other part of the world.— The Country is in a state of perpetual Revolution, and Mr Torlade told me that he had remained the whole Season at Georgetown; always in a state of extreme anxiety and not knowing from day to day what news he might receive— He said it was Spain that had made Don Miguel king of Portugal, and, that the English had acted a very selfish part in all their Relations with that Country—Mr Torlade expressed much anxiety concerning a new Treaty with France now before the Senate, and which stipulates for a reduction of our duties upon French wines— He fears that it will have an injurious effect upon our trade with Portugal; and tend to the exclusion of the wines from Madeira, Oporto and Lisbon— I told him the reduction of duties upon French wines would not preclude us from reducing them alike upon the wines of Portugal; but that we should perhaps expect some equivalent for it.— I wrote to Samuel Martin of Tennessee—and sent him the proposals of J. H. Eastburn with regard to the publication of an Edition of the Eulogy upon James Monroe in Tennessee—a project of Martin’s of which I have no doubt he has by this time thought better— I began also a Letter to my Son Charles, but was too unwell to finish it.
11. VI. Sunday.

I am closing the task of bringing up the arrears of this diary, which had been for upwards of four months running up, and which it has taken me, one of close application to retrieve—Mr Heuberger is the German Swiss, who some time since came here with Mr Hassler— He called again this morning, and brought with him two small boxes of antient medals coins and gems, and two sheets of paper with lists of the whole collection which he wishes to sell— He has eighteen hundred of them and supposes they would be well adapted to the Museum of any College or University, as undoubtedly they would—but this worthy Gentleman has mistaken the taste of the Country to which he has brought these Treasures. Democracy has no forefathers— It looks to no posterity— It is swallowed up in the present, and thinks of nothing but itself— This is the vice of Democracy and it is incurable— Democracy has no monuments— It strikes no Medals—It bears the head of no man upon a Coin— Its very essence is Iconoclastic—This is the Reason why Congress have never been able to erect a Monument to
Washington.— There is therefore no prospect for Mr Heuberger to dispose of his jewels here I had visits also from Mr Samuel Harrison Smith in the morning and from General Macomb in the Evening. But I had been up, quite unwell at two O’Clock in the night, and was so prostrated with debility, and the effect of medicine taken yesterday and this day that I could not attend public worship this Morning— In the afternoon I did attend and heard Mr Smith from Psalm 46.1. “God is our refuge and Strength—a very present help in trouble.”— Mrs Lee mentioned to me the Death of William H Eliot of Boston, of which the intelligence was this day received. I received also a Letter from S. A. Turner of Scituate—
12. VI. Monday.— Sun rose 7:20. Fahrenheit 24. growing colder.

Attended the House of Representatives. The appointment of the standing Committees was announced and I am Chairman of the Committee of Manufactures, a station of high responsibility, and perhaps of labour more burdensome than any other in the house— Far from the line of occupation in which all my life has been passed, and for which I feel myself not to be well qualified—I know not even enough of it to form an estimate of its difficulties—I only know that it is not the place suited to my acquirements and capacities such as they are. Yet as little as I esteem the Speaker I have no fault to find with him for the Appointment. The Petitions were called for, by States, commencing with Maine and proceeding Southward. I presented fifteen Petitions signed numerously by Citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia— I moved that they should be referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia.— The practice is for the member presenting the Petition to move that the reading of it be dispensed with, and that it be referred to the appropriate or to a select Committee—but I moved that one of the Petitions presented by me should be read; they being all of the same tenor, and very short. It was accordingly read— I made a very few remarks chiefly to declare that I should not support that part of the Petition which prayed for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. It is so long since I was in the habit of speaking to a popular Assembly—the Assemblies in which I had ever spoken extemporaneously have been comparatively speaking so little popular; and I am so little qualified by nature for an extemporaneous Orator, that I was at this time not a little agitated by the sound of my own voice— I was not more than five minutes upon my feet; but I was listened to with great attention, and when I sat down it seemed to myself as if I had performed an achievement.— So small and trivial are the things which often hang like burdens upon the Soul— I am grateful that this one has been removed— After the petitions were gone through the Resolutions to be offered were called for— Again by States; after which Mr. Wayne of Georgia moved that the House should resolve itself into a Committee of the whole upon the State of the Union. The Speaker requested General Adair to take the Chair— Mr Wayne then offered a Series of Resolutions distributing the President’s Messages into paragraphs, and referring each subject to a distinct Committee most of them were adopted as proposed; but the one to be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, made no mention of the Bank of the United States— George M’Duffie Chairman of that Committee moved as an Amendment to the Resolution, the words “so much as relates to the Bank of the United States” upon which a debate between these two members followed, in which Wayne pointedly referred to the contradictory opinions respecting the rechartering of the Bank of the United States,
contained in the President’s Message, and in the Annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury upon the finances—M’Duffie’s amendment prevailed by a large majority.— Charles A. Wickliffe moved an additional Resolution to refer the subject of internal improvement to a select Committee— Wayne said he had left it out, because there was nothing about internal improvement in the Message—and there had already been appointed a Committee on Internal Improvement, on a Resolution offered by C F Mercer of Virginia— Wickliffe’s Resolution was adopted in Committee of the whole, but in the house, was laid upon the table— The House adjourned about half past two. I spoke to the Clerk for the papers of sundry petitioners for pensions and for clearing a river, concerning which I had received Letters from Mr Joseph Richardson my Predecessor as Representative of the District and from S. A. Turner.— He said I should have them to-morrow Morning— I walked with John W. Taylor to his lodgings; but his dinner immediately came in and I promised to call upon him again. He said there had been a call of a meeting of National Republicans at Prentiss’s last Thursday; that five persons had attended. that he had received an invitation but was confined to his bed and could not attend— That the Anti-Masonic Members were not invited— Mrs Frye dined with us.
13. V:30. Tuesday.

As I was leaving home this morning to go to the House Dr Laurie stopped the Carriage to say that he came from the Subscribers to the Lyceum to request that I would deliver to them their first discourse which I was under a necessity of declining having a load of business upon me which makes it impossible for me to assume more—I rode to the Capitol stopping at Mr Everett’s lodgings but he was already gone— The Speaker took the Chair a few minutes after I reached the house; the States were again called over for Petitions— I presented in my turn four or five moving in the usual form that they should be referred to the appropriate Committees— Mr Ellsworth of Connecticut presented a Petition from a Claimant of demands upon France, before the year 1800 upon which a debate arose—he moved its reference to a Select Committee— Some other members moved its reference to the Committee for foreign Affairs— Howard of Baltimore moved to lay it on the table, alledging that the great body of the Claimants had committed their claims to the charge of one person, and did not wish Congress to do any thing with them this Session— But this was denied by Mr Drayton of South Carolina, who spoke for many of them— Mr. Everett—Mr. Hoffman of New-York, and Mr M’Duffie took part in the debate in which I also made a Speech.— I gave a short history of the Claims and stated their precise character to shew that they should go not to the Committee of foreign affairs, but to a select Committee— The house however by a considerable majority referred the petition to the Committee of Foreign Affairs— When the presenting of Petitions was gone through the Chaplain of the House was elected—The Revd. Reuben Post was chosen— A Resolution offered by C. F. Mercer was taken up—that here after there should at the commencement of each Session of Congress, be elected a Standing Committee upon Roads and Canals to consist of seven members— It was opposed by Mitchell of South Carolina, who was replied to by Mr Mercer— Mitchell moved to lay the Resolution on the Table which the House refused— Speight moved postponement till Monday—refused—then till to-morrow—refused—then to adjourn and that motion prevailed— I had asked Mr Everett to consent to exchange places with me on the Committees— To take my place as Chairman of the Committee of Manufactures, and to give me that of second upon the Committee of
foreign Relations, where he was placed; to which he readily agreed if the Speaker would consent which he said he did not believe he would— After the adjournment I went into the Speaker’s chamber, and proposed to him to authorize the exchange, but he said he had no power to make the alteration— That the appointment of Committees being once made was the act of the House, and he had no authority to change the arrangement in any manner. I referred him to an arrangement which had been made a few years since when John Randolph, was made Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, and George M’Duffie the second; and after a few days Mr Randolph was at his own request excused and M’Duffie acted as Chairman of the Committee during the remainder of the Session— He said it was the Act of the House upon a Letter from Mr Randolph himself and was granted with great reluctance— He then expatiated upon his discharge of his duties as Speaker upon the general expectation of the Nation— Upon importance of that place above all others, particularly at this time— I told him that so far as concerned myself I was satisfied— I had no complaint to make; and he had discharged his duty as Speaker—but I had two reasons for wishing to be excused—one that I did not feel myself competent for the Station which he had assigned to me—the other that the state of my health was not fitted to the burden which it imposed upon me— He repeated that he had no power over the arrangement of the Committees after the appointments were made. That the house alone could excuse me, and if they should, another distinguished Citizen from the East would be appointed, but not Mr Everett— The humiliation of asking to be excused by the house I cannot yet endure, and I shall submit to my fate— Gales sent to me again for a copy of my Speech on the relinquished claims upon France— I said he must send me the manuscript of his Reporter and I would revise it— I was obliged to write almost the whole of it over again, and it absorbed the Evening— I must very rarely make speeches in the house. It is double waste of Time—first to speak, and then to report.
14 V.15. Wednesday.

I was up again in the night between two and three O’Clock, and altho I returned to bed I had little Sleep— My mind is agitated and distressed with little prospect of relief, and with still less appearance of more favourable prospects hereafter— The Scene before me is such as might impel to desperation—and the wish that the Scene of earthly being were closed intrudes upon me, whenever I indulge in reflection— This state of mind brings wakeful nights of which I have now had three in succession with a prospect of I know not how many more— When Morning came I finished my version of the 51st. Psalm without more satisfaction— I wrote to Moses Whitson Salisbury Township Chester County Pennsylvania, from whom I received last Spring the 15 Petitions, which I presented on Monday to the House, and I enclosed to him a National Intelligencer containing my Speech on presenting the Petitions— Going to the House I stopped at Jonathan Elliot’s shop to leave my signalement, for his Directory, which he had sent me yesterday with blanks, requesting that they might be filled up and the note returned to him— Overtook Phineas L. Tracy and walked with him to the Capitol— Asked him to dine with me next Sunday, which he promised. He says he is well acquainted with Henry Brown the author of the Narrative of the Anti-masonic excitement in the Western Counties of New-York in 1827, 8 and 9— That Brown has lost that part of the Country, a bankrupt in fortune and reputation, and that his book is full of falsehood and misrepresentation, which I well knew before.
At the House of Representatives, precisely at Noon Dr Post commenced the business of the day with Prayer— The Speaker then took the Chair and called for Petitions. This occupied an hour—then came the unfinished business of yesterday; Mercer’s Resolution for the appointment hereafter, of a standing Committee of Roads and Canals. Speight made a Speech against it—and Ulysses F. Doubleday of New-York another. Mercer replied with great animation, and then Mitchell of South-Carolina replied to him— In the midst of Mitchell’s speech, the came a Message from the President, which suspended the debate— It was about the loss of the Ship Minerva—Referred to the Committee of Commerce— The House adjourned about two.— I had received the Commission of the Committee of Manufactures, and the reference to them of so much of the President’s Message as related to Manufactures and the Modification of the Tariff— M’Duffie, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means made several Reports. Hoffman the Chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs made one— I sent round a notification to all the members of the Committee of Manufactures, requesting their attendance at the room of the Committee immediately after the adjournment of the house— I called at the seat of Dr Condict, who had been a member of the same Committee at the last Session, to shew me the way to the Committee room— At Dr Condict’s seat I met Mr Clay, who appears to be in fine health— He said he would call and see me some Evening— He was nominated by the National Republican Convention at Baltimore yesterday for the Presidency of the United States at the next Election—165 votes out of 166. present naming him successively as their choice; and a Committee of 13 came last evening to inform him of his nomination.— I went with Dr Condict to the Room of the Committee on Manufacturers which is in the upper Story of the Capitol— There was no fire in the room, but there was in the adjoining chamber being that of the Committee of Foreign Relations— They were not in Session, and we took the Room, the whole Committee present—the members are Lewis Condict of New-Jersey James Findlay of Ohio, Henry Horn of Pennsylvania, Charles Dayan of New-York, J. T. H. Worthington of Maryland, and John S. Barbour of Virginia. There was some conversation among the members as to the best mode of proceeding by the Committee— A reduction of duties upon many of the Articles in the Tariff was understood by all to be the object to be effected—It was observed that it would be necessary to Review the Tariff’s of 1816. 1820. 1824. and 1828. and the effects severally produced by them.— That upon articles not in competition with our own the reduction might be large, and some articles made entirely free— It was suggested that communication might be held with the Secretary of the Treasury to ascertain the views and wishes of the Executive and if they had any plan in preparation upon this subject, which I promised to do— It was understood that as soon as the whole subject should be matured a Report should be prepared by the Chairman and submitted to the Committee— The Memorials from the Free Trade and Tariff Conventions are expected— It was proposed by one member that the Committee should meet twice a week, but as nothing is yet prepared the next meeting is to be called at the discretion of the Chairman, and he was desired to apply for another and more comfortable Committee Room— Adjourned about three. After I came home Captain Morrell, of the Schooner Antarctic was here— He says he has discovered many New Islands in the South Sea, and wishes to discover more— He asked for my advice, but I could give him none, though I told him I should be glad to give him all the assistance in my power.
15. IV:30. Thursday.

Began my version of the 52d. Psalm; and wrote a short Letter to my Son Charles— Read the Journal, and Address to the People of the United States of the Free-Trade Convention held at Philadelphia in the early part of October last— The Address was written by John M’Pherson Berrien, and though written in a gentlemanly Style, strikes me as very feeble in thought or argument— Mr Tracy of New-York called with William Heister, a member from Pennsylvania whom he introduced to me— Heister is the Successor of James A Buchanan— I attended at the House and was again belated— That is the Clerk was reading the Journal of yesterday when I entered the house— The Petitions were called for by States— I was just in time to present that of Constant Fobes Oakman, a Soldier of the Revolutionary War, and to move its reference to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— The House goes through this course daily, the dulness of which is abridged by the mode of despatching it— A succession of Resolutions was offered by sundry members with unanimous consent— One instructing the Committee of Ways and Means to bring in a Bill for repairing the Cumberland Road— After it had passed, Mr M’Duffie moved a reconsideration; remarking that while the House had been three days debating a question about roads and Canals, in which no principle was involved, the Resolution for squandering more money upon that inexhaustible sink of public funds the Cumberland Road had passed by an unanimous, unquestioned vote— It was an Instruction not even to enquire into the expediency, but positively to report a Bill.— The Speaker asked Mr M’Duffie if he moved a reconsideration—he said yes— Doddridge agreed to the reconsideration and that the enquiry into the expediency should be the Instruction instead of the order to bring in a bill; and so it passed—but it was all formal trifling in one case as well as in the other— No principle was settled by the order to bring in a Bill, which at any one of its three readings might be contested or rejected— The Resolutions offered by unanimous consent became so numerous that they were consuming the time, till upon one offered by D. J. Pearce Mr Mercer gave notice that it was the last he should suffer to pass— Mr Sevier the delegate from Arkansas Territory did nevertheless offer another Resolution but Mercer objected to its reception, and it was not received— Mr Mitchell of South-Carolina then finished his Speech against the future appointment of Standing Committees of Roads and Canals, Wilde of Georgia made a short speech against the Resolution, and Davis of Massachusetts a short Speech in its favour— Mitchell called for the yeas and nays, and the Resolution was carried by a vote of 96 to 90. It settled not one particle of principle; but it was a trial vote of the temper of the house upon the principle of internal improvement and the majority is so very small, in its favour that there is no doubt the minority will be able to defeat any project of that nature which may be brought forward, and which would promise any public utility— Several of the members voted against the Resolution upon party motives, who would willingly favour measures of internal improvement if they dared— Immediately after the question was taken the house adjourned over to next Monday— I found upon my Table a Letter from President Josiah Quincy recommending a person by the name of Henry Robinson, who wishes to obtain for his
son, Charles Robinson, a Midshipman’s Warrant.— Mr Findlay the member from Ohio came to my table, and asked for my influence in behalf of the same young man I promised to speak to the Secretary of the Navy in his behalf— Edward Everett said there was a Mr Caustin an agent of the claimants upon France prior to 1800. belonging to Baltimore who wished to be introduced to me— I told him I should be glad to see him— A Friend came also to take me by the hand, who said he had met me at the late Judge Peters’s near Philadelphia in October 1824. with Genl. La Fayette. In going to the Capitol this morning I met Rufus G. Amory, just arrived, who questioned me about the Speeches I have made in the house; and particularly about my presenting Petitions and then opposing the prayer of them— He seemed to doubt whether I ought not to have sent them back— There was a fire again last Evening at Georgetown, and three dwelling houses were consumed— We had this day Snow followed by a clear sharpening Northwester and Fahrenheit down to 6.
16. VII. Friday— Fahrenheit—4.

The coldest Morning since January 1821—the coldest within two degrees, that I have witnessed at Washington, in twenty winters— But there was no gale of wind; the cold was therefore not so searching as it is sometimes at a higher temperature— The Thermometer rose to 26. in the course of the day— I finished the version of the 52 and began that of the 53d. Psalm.— The day was absorbed in receiving visits and Letters; with an hour spent in walking round the Capitol— On returning to public life I find myself again besieged by a host of wild and foolish projectors from whom I had been for the last two years and nine Months, in a great measure released. They now swarm again— Edmund P. Dana the Geographical Book-maker came again, and asked me to present his petition to Congress—and I received a Letter signed Franklin (written most probably by himself) and earnestly recommending him to me— The man is Crazy— I declined presenting his petition, reminding him that I had stated objections to it when he was here before; and advising him to apply to some member to present his Petition, who would be willing to support it— He threatened again to give up the whole work—and said he should have done so already—but that he had received a warning— Major Duval is a remnant of the Revolutionary Army; of the Virginia Line—84 years of age as he informed me. He brought me an introductory Letter from Chief Justice Marshall—and is here to support before Congress a Military Claim in behalf of his old military associates— But his conversation with me was to bewail the existence of Slavery and the condition of the holders of Slaves in Virginia— Mr Hogan is a Son of the old Irishman who thirty years ago brought a large Fortune from Ireland to this Country to lose it here; whom Mr Monroe commissioned as Consul, first at the Havana, and afterwards at Valparaiso in Chili— The Son comes a a Representative from the 19th. District of New-York where he is settled; and from some remarks which he made on presenting a petition from a Revolutionary Soldier, for a pension, two days ago in the house, I perceive him to be a very well educated man, and in the use of polished and elegant language— The other members of Congress who called upon me, were of various characters and principles—and I received Letters from N.Biddle—John Williams, T. L. M’Kenney with a sheet of Indian History, Alexander Wilson Campbell, with a magnificent project for a literary
publication and establishment; for which he needs a loan of three or four thousand dollars; and from Henry Perrine who wants a grant of land to enable him to cultivate exotic plants for the benefit of the public— Coll. Abert spent most of the Evening with us
17. V. Saturday.

Finished the version of the 53d Psalm— The weather had gradually moderated all day yesterday, and I fancied a milder time was coming.— But just before daylight this morning the wind came round again to the North west with a brisk gale and a sharp frost stiffening all day long— My visitors this day were chiefly delegates from the National Republican Convention, which have just nominated Henry Clay for President, and John Sergeant for Vice-President of the United States— The morning visitors who came with Blunt talked about the weather— But those of the Evening spoke of the great harmony of their nomination at Baltimore, and of their sanguine hopes, and asked my opinions of their prospects— This introduced a long conversation upon Masonry and Anti-masonry—in which I gave my opinions with more freedom than discretion— They were asked, and it was not in my nature to conceal or disguise them. Mr Paine brought me a Letter of Introduction from Edward Everett. he is young man of great promise as a mathematician and astronomer, and is employed by direction of the Legislature in making the astronomic calculations for a new Map of the State of Massachusetts— He spoke of the observations and calculations made some years since by Joseph Lambert and William Elliot by order of Congress to fix the Longitude of the Capitol, as having placed it six Miles too far East—and said that Elliot’s observations of the Eclipse of last February were still worse— But that Mr Hassler had made a correct observation of the Eclipse. Two Gentlemen from the Relief Society came for a contribution— I received two Letters from Governor Lincoln, and wrote to Gray and Bowen of Boston; and to T. L. M’Kenney to send with the proof sheet of Indian History. I rode to the house of President Chapin of the College, and delivered to him a Letter mentioning the name of George Richard James Bowdoin Sullivan, as that of the young man soliciting the degree— Mr Chapin was at his dinner— I gave him the Letter enclosing the fees, 6: Dollars, and immediately came away— He told me that he had this day recommended the grant of the degree— I have read Mr M’Lane’s Report on the finances, and am now reading the proceedings of the free trade Convention held at Philadelphia the first week in October last.
18. VII. Sunday.— Fahrenheit 4.

The succession of cold weather still continues—severe beyond any thing that I ever knew before— The thermometer this morning at only 4 above 0 and at the middle of the day not more than 12—towards evening it moderated further— I made a version of the 54th Psalm. Heard at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Smith in the morning—from Job 14.17. [“]My transgression is sealed up in a bag, and thou sewest up mine iniquity.” His afternoon text was from Romans 12.9. “Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good.” I find the same defects in these Sermons as in all those
I have heard from Mr Smith since my return to Washington,—He preaches without Notes, and his mind is not so copiously stored with thoughts as it should be for extemporaneous discourse— His Sermons are by no means in the Style of Commonplace and some of his ideas are ingenious—but the soil of his mind is not rich, and he reproduces his seed not so much as thirty fold— Between the Services I had a visit from Mr Webster, who has very recently arrived— I asked him his views with regard to the diminution of duties in the Tariff, but he appeared to have formed no fixed opinion— I asked him if he thought a remission of six or seven Millions of duties and a reservation of five Millions a year for purposes of internal improvement, would be supported by the National Republicans; he thought they would. but said he would enquire and ascertain— The two brothers Everett Joseph Blunt, John W. Taylor—R. T. Payne, and Phineas L. Tracy dined with us—and I had evening visits from Mr William Jarvis, Mr White and Mr Hammond— I received a Letter from my Son Charles, and an Ontario Phenix Newspaper containing a Letter from R Rush to J. C. Spencer.
19. VI. Monday. Fahrenheit 16.

Began the version of the 55th. Psalm— General Peter B. Porter, and his nephew paid me morning visits—and Mr John Taliaferro of Virginia who left a Card— Dr Condict came with eight other Gentlemen, chiefly from New-Jersey, members of the late Convention at Baltimore, and Mr E. J Bacon, a Son of my old friend Ezekiel Bacon, who brought me Letters of Introduction from him and from A. B. Johnson of Utica. He said he would call upon me again— Mr Burke was formerly Editor of a newspaper at Frederick and then at Rockville, Maryland. He came here now as a Candidate for the Office of Doorkeeper of the Senate, for which he asked of me a Letter of Recommendation. I declined giving it, and told him I had done the same with another applicant before him— These visitors detained me so that the House were in Session before I reached the Capitol— I met Alexander H Everett just before, and he asked me to introduce him to the floor of the house, as a member of a State Legislature.— I did so, thinking that as such he was one of the privileged persons admissible upon the floor— I was shortly afterwards sent for at my Seat, and Carr the Door-keeper said that according to usage I must introduce Mr Everett to the Speaker. But the Speaker was then in the Chair and the house engaged in business— I asked Carr if I could introduce Mr Everett to the Speaker then— He thought not— I then said the Speaker would doubtless have no objection to Mr Everett’s remaining on the floor till the adjournment of the House— I found on returning to my Seat, and looking to the rules of the House that members of the State Legislatures are not among the persons admissible upon the floor— Among the Petitions presented was one from Mr. Arnold of Tennessee, from Samuel Martin of Campbell’s Station—relating to the Postage upon Newspapers and pamphlets payable by Printers. Arnold made a short Speech on presenting the Petition, which at his motion was ordered to be laid upon the Table and printed— General Dearborn, offered a Resolution, instructing the Committee of Ways and Means; to inquire into the expediency of reducing the duties on Teas, Coffee, Spices, Indigo and coarse Woollen, which gave rise to a debate, in which I took a part, whether the Resolution should be referred to the Committee of Ways and Means or to the Committee on Manufactures. It appeared that the Subject matter had been referred to both the Committees—the debate was suspended by the expiration of the hour, allotted to the Consideration of Resolutions. The house soon after adjourned. Joel B. Sutherland came up and introduced four or five of the members from
Pennsylvania to me, of whom were Coulter, Ihrie, and King who told me he was a native of Massachusetts— Sutherland wished Dearborn to withdraw his Resolution, but said if a vote should be taken upon it he should vote for referring it to the Committee on Manufactures— I walked with J. W. Taylor to his lodgings— He said there was a great effort making to get up Meetings of Anti-Masons to request Mr Wirt to decline his nomination, and that they would perhaps succeed— He said also that from the moment of his late address at the anti Masonic Meeting, all his oldest Masonic friends, who had ever adhered to him before had deserted him,—and turned against him with extreme violence— Mr Stone of New-York, and Mr Temple of Vermont spent the Evening here— Stone said he had made very little progress with his book; not having written more than sixty pages— We had a long and earnest conversation about anti-masonry— But Stone did not know that the four men who murdered Morgan were all Royal Arch Masons— I wrote a Letter to Governor Lincoln upon the subject.
20. IV:30. Tuesday

Mr Caustin is the agent of a number of the Claimants upon France, of the period preceding the year 1800. called and introduced himself— He reminded me of an application which he had made to me seven or eight years since at the Department of State for Documents relating to these claims, and, which from what he now said I incline to think I refused him—but of the application itself I have no Memory— Mr Doup is a Virginian who brought me an Old parchment indenture of the year 1719–20. being a conveyance by Lease and Release to a person named John Blunden of what he said was a whole Square in the City of Kilkenny in Ireland— The Conveyance was executed by several persons among whom a woman named Dillon and her husband Mr Doup said his wife’s uncle, named Dillon, was lineally descended from the woman who executed the Indenture and claimed by descent from her— I told him the first thing would be to prove the lineage; and for this he was not at all prepared. There are at least three generations to prove and no public registers to which they can recur— Then with regard to the title I asked Mr Doup to leave the Indenture with me till to-morrow Morning when I would give him my opinion upon it. He left it accordingly: The Revd. Mr Skinner and two other Gentlemen from the Columbian College, came to invite my attendance at their Commencement to-morrow—to be held at Mr Post’s Church— I promised to attend as long as I could compatibly with my duty to the House of Representatives— I was again detained so that I found the house in Session— And in the call of States for the presentation of Petitions, Massachusetts was already past— After they had all gone through however I obtained the unanimous consent of the house to present a Petition from East-Middleborough, for the Establishment of a Post-Office there— It was according to the usual custom referred to the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, of which Coll. Richard M. Johnson is Chairman— I recommended the petition to his charge; and he promised to give special attention to it.— There was a debate in the house whether several petitions and memorials should be referred to the Committee of Commerce, or to that of Internal Improvement—and by a vote taken a large Class of Cases usually referred heretofore to the Committee of Commerce was now transferred to the Committee of internal improvement— Mr William Babcock one of the members from the State of New-York said he wished to have some Conversation with me, and I agreed to receive
him at my house any morning or Evening as might suit his convenience— On my way home from the house I stopped at the Treasury, and had an hour of conversation with him upon the projected modification of the Tariff— I told him I should propose to reserve as much as five Millions a year to purposes of Internal Improvement— He said he thought it would be impossible to obtain the assent of Congress or of the President to the reservation of so large a sum— I argued the point with him, and he said he would report my remarks to the President—an effectual damper for them— I said there was one point of view in which perhaps the President might be reconciled to it—as a means of strengthening the defences of the Country— Such a reservation might serve the purpose of a Treasure, without the inconvenience of hoarding— In peace it might be applied to internal improvement, and in prospect of War be a fund ready provided for the emergencies of the Times— Mr Thomas Newton came and introduced two of his Constituents Messrs Carr and Harold to me—members of the late Baltimore Convention—and Mr Joseph Blunt was here in the Evening— I received a Letter from George Sullivan, enclosing one for President Chapin of the College.
21. V:30. Wednesday.

An Italian by the name of Pinistri came with a plan for improving the Hall of the House of Representatives, so that the Speakers may be more easily heard. He said Mr Verplanck was Chairman of a Committee to which his memorial had at the last Session of Congress been referred— I told him he must then go to Mr Verplanck again— He said that would be of no avail that Mr Verplanck had nothing to say against the plan, but that he thought it would cost too much— I said he must reason with Mr Verplanck and convince him that it would not— I returned to Mr Doup his Indenture which I had examined, and could find no claim of title to the descendants of Dillon, unless by a reversion as heirs of the grantee John Blunden. He said Mr. Lawless of Missouri knew the land described in the Indenture, and said that it was whole square in the City of Kilkenny, covered with dwelling houses, and certainly worth several hundred thousands of dollars— He said what had first called the attention of his relatives to the subject was that a Gentleman, who came a year or two since from Ireland had said that it was understood there that the heirs to this Estate were in America— He then asked my advice what they should do—observing that the persons who would be benefited by the recovery of the property, if it could be recovered, had met with misfortunes, and were in straitened circumstances— I told him I could not upon the conveyance and the facts as he had submitted them to me, recommend to the parties interested, any measure which would involve expence— They might perhaps by a Correspondence in Ireland, ascertain more of the present state of the property and they might see if they could trace the lineage down regularly to the claimant— These were the first things to be done and the result of them might lead to the expediency of them doing something more— Mr Doup asked me, what was my charge for my advice—and upon my answering, nothing; expressed himself as very grateful for it— I attended the Commencement of the Columbian College, at Dr Post’s Church— I found them already in the church at half past ten, and gave to President Chapin while in the pulpit the Letter for him which I received last Evening from George Sullivan— I explained also the error in which I had been that his Son still retained the name of Sullivan— His name is now George, Richard, James Bowdoin. The President promised that the degree should be conferred accordingly.
I remained until the performances of the Candidates for degrees were completed but could not wait to witness the conferring of the degrees— It was past twelve when I left the Church and I found the house had been in Session about half an hour— The turn of the members from Massachusetts for presenting Petitions was passed, but after the States and Territories had been all called I found an opportunity to present the Petition from sundry inhabitants of Scituate and the neighbouring Towns, for the improvement of North-river; which at my motion was referred to the Committee on internal improvement. Mr Everett invited me to attend at his lodgings this Evening a small Meeting of friends to consider the question with regard to the Modification of the Tariff— I had some conversation, with Mr C. F. Mercer on the same Subject; and intimated to him a wish that there might be about five Millions of Revenue reserved, annually for specific purposes of internal improvement. He said that he should be entirely in favour of it, but thought it doubtful whether it could be carried through— I have the same doubts perhaps in higher degree— Mr Francis Johnson of Kentucky with a Mr Willis called upon me this afternoon— The were members of the late Baltimore President-making Convention. At seven in the Evening I went to Mr Everett’s lodgings, and there met Messrs. Appleton, I. C. Bates, L. Condict, Dearborn, Ellsworth, Evans of Maine, Holmes, Huntington, Jenifer, Letcher, Pendleton, Tracy John W. Taylor, Whittlesey of Ohio, and one other— Much conversation ensued, with regard to the course to be taken by the friends of domestic Industry— It resulted in an Agreement to hold another and larger Meeting next Monday Evening, and in the meantime a Committee not to be confined to the members of the present Meeting, to be appointed by the Chairman, Taylor, to report an opinion for discussion as to what further is to be done— I came home about ten— My Son John’s youngest child is much recovered; but the eldest is very unwell.
22. VI:15. Thursday. Fahrenheit 4.

Finished the version of the 55th. and began that of the 56th. Psalm. Mr Bell the Senator from New-Hampshire called to see me, this morning, before the Meeting of the Houses— He said the nomination of Martin Van Buren, as Minister to Great-Britain was now before the Senate, and some of the members inclined to reject it; but he doubted himself whether that course would be wise or politic— I told him I thought it so far otherwise; that I had not supposed any Senator would vote against the nomination with a purpose of rejecting it— I thought Van Buren had disgraced himself when Secretary of State, by pandering to palm a prostitute upon decent Society—and disgraced the Country by his Instructions to M’Lane, upon his Mission to England— But to reject the nomination of him now would bring him back with increased power to do mischief here—would make way for another appointment certainly not less profligate than himself; and would have abroad an effet unfavourable to this Country similar to that which his own obnoxious Instructions have produced. I thought therefore the rejection of him would do no good and might do much harm. I found the House in Session, and the Clerk reading the Journal of yesterday— Mr Whittlesey Chairman of the Committee of Claims had reported 38 bills, and about 25 of them this day passed through the Committee of the whole, were reported to the house without amendment, and then passed to the third reading— There were three successive Committees of the whole, of which John W. Taylor—Jesse Root, and Dr Condict were successively Chairman— The Bills were chiefly such as had passed the House of Representatives at the last Session of Congress.
I sent round notice to the members of the Committee of Manufactures to meet immediately after the adjournment of the house. I read to them the draught of a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, which I had written enquiring for information, which was adopted with an amendment— Mr Bouldin of Virginia had moved in the house a Resolution calling on the Committee to obtain and report to the house certain information— I proposed to enclose also a copy of this Resolution to the Secretary of the Treasury, and to ask the information of him, which was agreed to— Mr Worthington was the only member of the Committee absent— Some of the members intimated that they would prefer hereafter to meet in the Morning, before the Meeting of the House— John W. Taylor called here in the Evening, and mentioned that he was somewhat embarrassed with regard to the appointment of the Committee with which he had been charged last Evening— He thought I had inclined not to be one of the Committee myself—in which I told him he had understood me correctly— He said he had thought of Mr Clay, Mr Webster, and Mr Josiah S. Johnston, all of whom I thought well-selected— He said John Davis of whom he spoke very highly appeared to distrust a little the consonancy of Mr Clay’s views with the interest of internal industry in New-England— I supposed this might have originated in the sort of Manifesto of Mr Clay’s present political opinions, issued for him in the Richmond Whig.— John H. Pleasants’s paper entirely devoted to him— I told Taylor I had some suspicion Davis was somewhat distrustful of me also, though I knew not exactly the reason why?— Taylor spoke of his own situation, and of the certainty that after the new census, his vicinage would be so districted as to exclude him from Congress— I told him I expected the same thing. He spoke of the probable establishment of a branch of the United States Bank at Albany. I wrote to George Sullivan.
23. V:15. Friday. Fahrenheit 5.

Mr Post, the Chaplain of the House of Representatives, and the Revd. Mr Marsh from Connecticut came this morning and informed me that they were intending to invite a general meeting of the friends of Temperance to promote in this respect the cause of morality— Societies for that purpose have within these few years been formed in most of our populous Cities and in many other places— These Gentlemen came to ask my attendance at the Meeting; that I would preside, and address the Meeting. I told them that I would very cheerfully attend the Meeting; but that I must decline either to preside or to address the Meeting; having special reasons for avoiding to make myself in any manner conspicuous before the Public here—which Mr Post said he well understood— I found the house in Session and the call for Petitions just commencing— After the Petitions and Resolutions were gone through, nearly thirty private Bills, mostly those reported from the Committee of Claims by Mr Whittlesey were read the third time, and passed; without amendment or notice— Then there were twelve others, passed in Committee of the whole House, reported and passed to a third reading— There were two, upon which after they had passed through the Committee of the whole, and were taken up in the house, Mr Wickliffe himself asked some explanations of Mr Whittlesey—with regard to one of them he was satisfied and allowed it to pass— The other was a bill for the relief of the legal Representatives of William Hull—an allowance of Salary to him as Governor of Michigan, for some Months, while he was a prisoner in Canada; and while he was receiving pay as a Major General— Wickliffe objected to the passage of this Bill, and after a short debate, it was lost by a considerable majority— There was not much to be said in its favour, excepting as an apology for a charitable donation to an indigent family— Yet I voted for it— I had received a Letter from Nathan Dean and Cushing Otis of Scituate in behalf of
Elisha James a petitioner for a Revolutionary Pension. I took it to Henry Hubbard, the Chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, who promised me to report a Bill, at the next meeting of the House— They adjourned over till Tuesday, on Account of Christmas. I received a Letter from W. L. Stone, enquiring about the Acts of Parliament against the administration of unlawful Oaths— After the adjournment I went into the Library to find Stone; but he was not there— After this I called upon Mr Webster, at Gadsby’s— While I was with him Mr Appleton came in— I invited them both to dine with me on Christmas day; but Mr Webster, is going to-morrow to Annapolis—to argue a cause before the Court of Appeals of Maryland— There was a report circulated in the House this day of the decease of Mr Wirt. He has the prevailing influenza which is now epidemic along the whole Sea coast, and proved fatal in many cases. He has been for several days very dangerously ill— After I returned from the House Count Lehmanowsky came to me with an Exile from Poland, who has lost his fortune in the recent insurrection there; has two Sons now prisoners to the Russians, and is soliciting contributions to enable him to return home. John’s child Mary Louisa has been several days sick, and is now extremely ill—The other, Fanny has much recovered.
24. VI. Saturday— Snow, Rain and Clear

Finished my version of the 56th. and began that of the 57th. Psalm. For the last two or three days an offuscation before my eyes has deprived me of the power of writing, and almost of reading in the evening—and has almost disqualified me before daylight in the morning— The cries of anguish of the child over my head distract my mind, and pierce me to the Soul— She has the Scarlet fever very severely and suffering extreme pain— It absorbs my Soul till the power of composition sinks into impotence— A Quaker by the name of Chevalier came this morning to shew me his patented invention of an improved mode of driving oakum into the seams of the planks of ships; of which he had a drawing, and asked my opinion— I told him I could form no opinion about it— That it must be tested by experiment. Mr William Babcock is a member of the House; from Ontario County, New-York, formerly represented by Robert R Rose. Babcock told me his own Story— He was a Mason of three degrees; and connected with the publication of a newspaper— For sometime after the death of Morgan he disbelieved the fact, and his paper treated as infamous calumnies all the charges against the Masons as being guilty of his blood— About a Month after the event, a Mason, who was under very great obligations to him, told him as a Masonic secret that Morgan had been murdered; at which he was so much shocked that he immediately renounced his connection with the order, and his paper from that time took the Anti-masonic side— He immediately became an object of violent persecution by the Masons of his neighbourhood, which has continued to this day— At the head of it is the man who gave him the information, and who owes to him everything that he has in the world— Every kind of slander that could be invented has been circulated against him— All his Masonic friends have deserted and taken part against him; and that has finally made him a member of Congress; for he is not an educated man—is a shopkeeper miller and mechanic— With all this he told me he had called to see me to give me a caution— He had been told by G. H. Wheeler, a Jackson member of Congress from his State, that there was now a formal design in process of execution, to get me into a difficulty in the House of Representatives— That it is of Masonic origin, and that the agent for its execution is Mr Root—a high Mason. Mr Babcock advised me therefore not to take part in any debates upon trifling subjects— He thinks also that Mr Clay now expects that the Jackson Masons will come over to him after Jackson’s second term
of Office shall have expired—but that he deceives himself and that Richard M Johnson will be their man— He says Richard M Johnson may be plaistered up into a hero, and that will be enough to fashion him into a Candidate for the Office of President. I had visits from sundry members of Congress, and from Colonel Woolley of the army with Mr Pugh from the State of Illinois— This Gentleman has a project for making a Rail-road from Lake Michigan to the Illinois-river—to be substituted in the place of a Canal—for which an Appropriation to a large amount of public Lands, has already been made by Congress. Mr Pugh wishes the Appropriation to be transferred, from the Canal to a Rail-way and solicits my assistance to carry this measure through the house— I received the cards also of Daniel Wardwell, Charles Dayan, Samuel Beardsley, F. G. Jewett, Ulysses F. Doubleday Churchill C. Cambreleng, and William Slade, members of the House, the last from Vermont; all the rest from New-York— I called at the Department of State and enquired of the Chief Clerk, who is still Mr Daniel Brent; if the claim upon France of William Holmes of Plymouth, from whom I received this morning a Letter upon the subject was upon the files, and I found it was— I asked Mr Brent for a copy of the entries upon the files in that case, which he promised to send me next Tuesday.— He gave me also a new Catalogue of the Library and promised me a Collection of the documents of the last Session of Congress— I then called upon General Cadwalader at his lodgings, and invited him to dine with me to-morrow; but he said he had engaged the Senators from Pennsylvania, Wilkins and Dallas to dine with him— Cadwalader is here on the concerns of the Bank of the United States, somewhat uncertain whether it will be proper for the Bank to apply for a new Charter at the present Session of Congress— He told me much of the result of his inquiries, and particularly a characteristic dialogue between him, and Samuel Smith, chairman of the Committee of Finance in the Senate—very anxious for the rechartering of the Bank; but not sure that he can vote for it, at this Session of Congress— I told Cadwalader that I was so decidedly in favour of the Bank, that I had on last passing through Philadelphia, divested myself of all personal interest in its concerns— He said Mr M’Duffie had told him he had done the same— I was unable to write this Evening— The Child Louisa most distressingly ill—and Mrs Nowlan, was this morning called away to her daughter in Law, who is in Childbed.
25. V. Sunday— Christmas— Snow—thaw—frost

A morning of much distress from the illness and cries of the child, but hopes are given that she is better— I attended the morning Public worship at the Capitol, and heard Mr Post, from Luke 2.11. “For unto you is born this day in the City of David a Saviour: which is Christ the Lord.” Mr Post is a Presbyterian; but his Sermon as well as his text was adapted to the day.— The house was very thin; and there was no person there to raise the tune to sing the first hymn: for the second and third there was— After Church I invited Mr Bell, the Senator from New-Hampshire, and Blunt to dine with me, which they did— I asked also Mr Foot, Senator from Connecticut, but he was engaged— I called upon General Dearborn, and Mr Ellsworth of Connecticut, and invited them—but Dearborn was confined to the house with the Influenza, and Mr Ellsworth was engaged— William Lee came in while I was there; and Samuel H Smith was there when I first went in— All conversation now is about the influenza and weather.
I attended afternoon Service at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from Matthew 12.38. [“]Then certain of the scribes and of the Pharisees answered, saying, Master, we would see a sign from thee”— In this as in all Mr Smith’s discourses, his doctrine is drawn by a long deduction, remotely from his text— In this case it was that religion was burdensome and disagreeable to the human mind—which was always calling for evidence and proof other than that which it possessed— This is ingenious; but not in the beaten track.— On returning home I met at my door Edward J. Coale, who wanted to see my Son John— Coale had seen Dr. Watkins in prison yesterday, and found he had been incensed by some foolish tale of something having been said by my Son, which the Doctor took for an insult upon his family— I told him there could be no foundation for it, and I afterwards asked my Son to see Coale, and enable him to refute the falsehood— We had company to dinner— Nathan Appleton, George Bancroft, Saml Bell, Joseph Blunt, Lewis Condict, Dutee J. Pearce, John Reed, William S. Smith—William L Stone— Mr Webster went yesterday to Annapolis, and Mr Newton who had promised me to come, sent me an excuse this day— Vetoed by the Influenza— I received a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury acknowledging the receipt of two from me as Chairman of the Committee of Manufactures, and one from Christopher Hughes at Stockholm—and Cards from A. Dickins—and from T. F. Foster, and H. G. Lamar, members of the House from Georgia—
26. V:30. Monday. Snow.

Mrs Adams has watched the two last Nights with her sick grandchild Mary Louisa, severely afflicted with the Scarlet fever. I finished the version of the 57th. and began that of the 58th. Psalm— This employs on the average about two hours every morning, and is delightful occupation when I fancy myself successful—that is about one Psalm in five— The rest is teizing and bitter disappointment as especially it was this morning. I had a succession of visitors all this morning— Mr Pendleton, member of the house from New York, read to me a set of Resolutions, which he proposes to offer to the House, declaratory of the appellate Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of the United States, from the Courts of the States in criminal cases— Of the expediency of his presenting them I had some doubts; but did not think proper to discourage him, as he seemed anxious to make a Speech in support of them; and as it may be productive of good results.— He said he had as yet mentioned them only to Mr Everett—but I advised him to communicate them to Mr Evans of Maine, Mr Davis of Massachusetts—Ingersoll and Ellsworth of Connecticut, Taylor of New-York and Doddridge of Virginia— He said he wished to bring them forward as soon as possible— Rather to-morrow than later— Mr Clay asked me how I felt upon turning boy again to go into the House of Representatives— I told him that hitherto I had found the labour light enough, but the house had not yet got to business— He repeated several times that I should find my situation extremely laborious and that I knew right well before— Labour I shall not refuse so long as my hand—my eyes and my brain do not desert me—but what shall I do for that which I cannot give?— Mr Clay spoke of the reduction of the Tariff, and said there were other points to be considered, besides the taking off of the duties— One was changing the mode of Valuation which he deemed highly important— Another was shortening the credits of importations, and introducing a system of cash payments as for the Public Lands— A third was the expediency of increasing the duties upon some of the protected Articles, so
so as to make them nearly prohibitory— To increase the duties for the express purpose of diminishing the revenue, was an idea well deserving of meditation, and which had not occurred to me— I asked whether in the gracious operation of remitting taxes, there would not be a mixture of harshness in extending the protective system, and a danger of increasing the discontents of the Southern States, already bitterly complaining of the unequal operation of the duties— He said the discontents were almost all, if not entirely imaginary or factitious, and in almost all the Southern States had in a great measure subsided— Here is one great error of Mr Clay— He spoke of the Report upon Iron to the New-York Tariff Convention, and of their Address to the People which he said was an unequal composition— I wished this conversation to be extended, but others came in and it was interrupted— Of the other visitors Mr Dickerson, the Senator from New-Jersey was the most remarkable, and Mr John Branch, late Secretary of the Navy, and now a member of the House from North-Carolina left a card here. Mr D’Homergue the Silk man, brought me a Letter of Introduction from P. S. Duponceau— There is a Bill before the House appropriating forty-thousand dollars for him to instruct sixty persons in the art of making silk— It was reported at the last Session of Congress by the Committee of Agriculture, but not passed. It is to be brought forward again this Session— Dr Huntt visited me as my friend and Physician—and gave me some advice.
